fields.description: When a new name and password is entered in a form and the form is submitted, the browser asks if the password should be saved. Thereafter when the form is displayed, the name and password are filled in automatically or are completed as the name is entered. An attacker with local access could obtain the cleartext password from the browser cache.
fields.summary: Password type input with autocomplete enabled

comments.body: Vika, please take a look at this issue and comment.  Will this be addressed in the new Admin console?

Confirm, a user is prompted to save the password by the browser and it can later be viewed in the browser's cache. The fix seems to be to simply add "autocomplete=off" to the password input field in the login form. Should be easy to fix in either current admin console or in a new one.
My browser already allows me to choose to not save my password.  Why are you making this choice for me without asking first?

Good point, [~gholms]. I can see how disabling autocomplete can help system hardening. This prevents problems due to users not paying attention to all dialog boxes and accidentally choosing to save password on a browser (i.e., not putting some security choices into the hands of users when security of a system is a concern). Disabling password autocomplete makes sense for security-sensitive systems (and to me in general), but whether we want it to be the only option available should be considered.
[~kgill], we need to have an option (a config param?) of disabling autocomplete in User Console to satisfy use cases of customers who do not want their users to save password in browser.
[~tjcramer], should this ticket be turned into a GUI one?
I think this is irrelevant now since it applied to the old admin GUI.
[~dkavanagh], is autocomplete disabled in the new UI?
in 4.0, we don't save that information ourselves. If the user chooses to let the browser remember their password, it will fill in as they type their username.
[~dkavanagh], I believe this bug is about having the ability to force the "no autocomplete" on users when it's desired for system security. See comments above.
The user has the option of not saving the password. The browser ask before it saves the password, so they simply select "no" or "never for this site".

In security hardened clouds, cloud admins need an ability to forcefully disable autocomplete for all users, regardless of their personal choice. Compromise of one password can lead to compromise of the entire cloud, so leaving the choice of saving the password in the browser up to a user is not always acceptable and we should provide a way to disable autocomplete completely for all users.

sigh, we worked so hard to get that working for users vs storing them ourselves.

Do do this, we'd just need to rename fields on the login form, so the browser doesn't recognize them. Any reason we didn't have to do this for 3.4?

I think adding "autocomplete=off" to the form field should do the trick (see previous comments). 

Also, maybe it makes sense to make this disabling of autocomplete configurable by the cloud admin (via a console config param) so that it could work both ways (UX vs security).

I'll point out that we can't turn this off per user since the login form is
presented the same for any user (i.e. we don't know if they want it turned
off till they identify themselves). We can only turn it off globally.
Globally is exactly what's needed.
https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/476
now, only sets autocomplete flag on password/secret_key fields
[~kgill] can you provide insight on how to verify this? I know from using the console lately that we have the browser set to handle it, but my feelings aren't really enough for proper QA. :) Thanks!

verified browser password save is working as expected.

verification done on mac osx 10.9.2, FF 28.0
